sections.heading: Third Person Pronouns
sections.content:
Third person pronouns in Japanese include 彼 (he), 彼女 (she), and their variations. However, these pronouns have dual meanings (also "boyfriend/girlfriend") and are less commonly used than English "he/she." Japanese often prefers names, descriptive phrases, or context over pronouns.

彼は学生です "He is a student" or "My boyfriend is a student" 彼女は先生です "She is a teacher" or "My girlfriend is a teacher" あの人は誰ですか "Who is that person?" (neutral, clearer)

children.heading: Dual meaning
children.content: Meaning 1: He 彼は学生です "He is a student" Meaning 2: Boyfriend 彼はやさしい "My boyfriend is kind" Context determines meaning Ambiguity possible

children.heading: When to use as "he"
children.content: ✓ Formal writing ✓ Academic contexts ✓ When gender is relevant ✓ Translating foreign text Not always natural Context should be clear

children.heading: Avoiding ambiguity
children.content: If meaning "he" (not boyfriend): その男性は... "That man..." あの人は... "That person..." 田中さんは... "Tanaka..." Clearer alternatives Less ambiguous

children.heading: Dual meaning
children.content: Meaning 1: She 彼女は先生です "She is a teacher" Meaning 2: Girlfriend 彼女はきれいだ "My girlfriend is pretty" Same ambiguity as 彼 Context crucial

children.heading: When to use as "she"
children.content: ✓ Formal writing ✓ Academic contexts ✓ When gender needs emphasis ✓ Translating Not always natural speech Consider alternatives

children.heading: Avoiding ambiguity
children.content: If meaning "she" (not girlfriend): その女性は... "That woman..." あの人は... "That person..." 山田さんは... "Yamada..." Clearer options

children.heading: Gender-neutral, polite
children.content: あの人は誰ですか "Who is that person?" あの人は医者です "That person is a doctor" Used for: Anyone Gender: Neutral Formality: Polite Distance: Far from both Most common alternative

children.heading: Advantages
children.content: ✓ No gender assumption ✓ No boyfriend/girlfriend confusion ✓ Natural in conversation ✓ Polite and respectful ✓ Widely appropriate Preferred over 彼/彼女

sections.heading: この人/その人 (kono hito/sono hito)

children.heading: Distance-based "person"
children.content: この人は友達です "This person is my friend" その人は誰？ "Who is that person?" この: Near speaker その: Near listener あの: Far from both Demonstrative + person

children.heading: 彼ら (karera) - They (male/mixed)
children.content: 彼らは学生です "They are students" Male or mixed group Formal contexts Less common in speech

children.heading: 彼女ら (kanojora) - They (female)
children.content: 彼女らは看護師です "They are nurses" All-female group Formal/written Rare in speech

children.heading: 彼女たち (kanojotachi) - They (female)
children.content: 彼女たちは来ます "They will come" Female group More natural than 彼女ら

children.heading: あの人たち (ano hitotachi) - Those people
children.content: あの人たちは誰ですか "Who are those people?" Gender-neutral plural Natural and polite Common choice

children.heading: Use names
children.content: Instead of: 彼は来る Better: 田中さんが来る "Tanaka is coming" Most natural Clearest option Always appropriate

children.heading: Use descriptive terms
children.content: その男性 "that man" その女性 "that woman" あの子 "that child" あの方 "that person" (polite) Specific and clear Natural Japanese

children.heading: Use titles/roles
children.content: 先生は "the teacher" 社長は "the president" お客様は "the customer" Professional contexts Respectful

children.heading: Modern considerations
children.content: あの人 "that person" その方 "that person" (polite) 友達 "friend" 相手 "the other person/partner" No gender assumption Inclusive language

children.heading: Respectful reference
children.content: あの方はどなたですか "Who is that person?" (polite) その方は先生です "That person is a teacher" (polite) Polite form of 人 Shows respect Formal situations

children.heading: Often unnecessary
children.content: With context: 学生です "(He/She) is a student" Topic established, pronoun dropped Very natural

children.heading: Continuing reference
children.content: 田中さんは医者です。忙しいです。 "Tanaka is a doctor. (He) is busy." Name first, then omit Clear from context

children.heading: When 彼/彼女 means romantic partner
children.content: 彼ができた "I got a boyfriend" 彼女と別れた "I broke up with my girlfriend" Context makes it clear No ambiguity here

children.heading: Avoiding confusion
children.content: To clarify "he/she" (not romantic): その男の人 "that man" その女の人 "that woman" Or use name Be specific

children.heading: Western influence
children.content: 彼/彼女 as "he/she": Borrowed from Western languages Translation convenience Not traditional Japanese Still not fully natural Japanese historically used: Names, titles, context More natural approach

children.heading: When pronouns are appropriate
children.content: Academic papers Translations Formal documents News reports (sometimes) More acceptable in writing Still consider alternatives

children.heading: Respectful terms
children.content: あの方 (polite) その方 (polite) あちらの方 (that person over there) Shows respect Professional settings

children.heading: Overusing 彼/彼女
children.content: Unnatural: 彼は学生です。彼は真面目です。⚠️ Natural: 田中さんは学生です。真面目です。✓ "Tanaka is a student. (He) is serious." Use name, then omit More natural

children.heading: Assuming 彼/彼女 always means romantic
children.content: Context matters: 学術論文で彼は... (he in academic paper) 昨日彼と... (with my boyfriend yesterday) Academic vs. personal context

children.heading: Using when name is known
children.content: Avoid: 彼は来る (when you know his name) Better: 田中さんが来る "Tanaka is coming" Names are more natural

children.heading: この/その/あの person pattern
children.content: この人: Near me "This person (here with me)" その人: Near you "That person (near you)" あの人: Away from both "That person (over there)" Distance determines choice

children.heading: Basic
children.content: Using alternatives: あの人は誰ですか "Who is that person?" 田中さんは学生です "Tanaka is a student" 先生は忙しいです "The teacher is busy" Better than pronouns

children.heading: Intermediate
children.content: Without pronouns: 田中さんは医者です。毎日 忙しく働いています。 "Tanaka is a doctor. (He) works busy every day." あの人は先生だと思います。 よく学校で見かけます。 "I think that person is a teacher. I often see (them) at school." 友達が結婚しました。とても 幸せそうです。 "My friend got married. (They) seem very happy."
